International Tributes to the History of Flight
First American to Orbit the Earth
Strapped into the contour couch of his Friendship 7
capsule, John Glenn hoped to do what no American
had ever done - orbit the Earth. As thousands wit-
nessed from nearby beaches and millions more
watched on TV, he lifted off from Cape Canaveral at
9:47 a.m.
An autopilot failure forced Glenn to fly the craft
manually. But that was the least of his problems. Far
more serious was the threat that the heat shield had
come free and Friendship 7 would burn up on re-
entry. The moment of truth came after 4 hours and
55 minutes in which Glenn had traveled 83,450
miles and completed three earth orbits. Friendship 7
reentered the atmosphere safely, splashing down
in the Atlantic.
The full-color cachet pictures Marine Lt. Col. John
Glenn, Jr., the oldest of the original seven Project
Mercury astronauts, standing next to his Friendship
7 capsule. The craft was boosted into space by 365,000
pounds of thrust from an Atlas D rocket.
Mint Stamp: The mint stamp on this Cover was issued
by the United States in 1962, simultaneously with
Glenn's flight. It shows Friendship 7 in space, orbit-
ing the Earth.
Postmark: This Cover was postmarked in Cape Can-
averal, Florida on February 20, 1984, the anniversary
of America's first earth-orbiting flight.
• Postal Commemorative Society
